Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Reaction dynamics study of biomolecular ions with electronically excited singlet molecular oxygen using guided-ion-beam scattering and direct dynamics trajectory methods
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project supported by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Jianbo Liu and his research group at the Queens College of the City University of New York will study the reaction of biomolecules such as amino acids and dipeptides with a reactive oxygen species called singlet molecular oxygen (^1 O2). Singlet O2 is generated in nature from normal oxygen molecules in the presence of visible/ultraviolet light from the sun. The reaction of biomolecules with singlet O2 is not only interesting from the standpoint of chemical reaction dynamics, but is also an important topic because of connections to biological processes such as aging and diseases (e.g. cataracts and some skin cancers), as well as photodynamic therapy for cancer and photochemical transformations of biological species in the atmosphere and oceans. Professor Liu and his team will conduct a systematic study of the reaction of biomolecules with singlet O2, aimed at achieving a molecular level understanding of the reaction mechanism and reaction kinetics/dynamics. The experimental systems range from isolated biomolecules in the gas phase in the absence of water, through gas-phase hydrated biomolecules with a few water molecules attached, to biomolecules in liquid water. The experimental techniques employed include guided-ion-beam scattering and electrospray ionization mass spectrometry. Since the photosensitization method for producing singlet O2 often produces ozone and other undesirable species that complicate the results, Professor Liu's laboratory will employ a chemical technique to generate pure singlet O2 for reactions with biomolecules. The experimental work will be complemented by theoretical calculations, including ab initio electronic structure calculations and direct dynamics trajectory simulations.

Professor Liu's research program will train not only graduate and senior undergraduate students at CUNY, but will also involve high school students through his participation in the Queensborough Bridge Program and MARC-U*STAR Program, which engage community college students and minority students in science. Also, in coordination with the CUNY pre-college summer research program, students from local high schools will work in the Liu laboratory, and their results will be translated into competitive science fair research projects. This research program is also integrated into Professor Liu's formal course teaching. He will use his research equipment to develop new experiments (e.g., simulations of ion trajectories, and collision-induced dissociation of molecules) in Physical Chemistry and Instrumental Analysis Laboratories.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Singlet oxygen is a highly reactive oxygen species that can be generated in nature and within biological systems from normal oxygen molecules which people breathe.  Proteins are the major target for singlet oxygen attack.  Understanding how chemical reactions with singlet oxygen change the functions of and destroy the proteins in biological systems could make it possible to design procedures for slowing down oxidatively generated damage to the living things or otherwise controlling them to produce desired results.  Paradoxically, because singlet oxygen oxidizes and destroys cells, it could be harnessed for positive ends, for example, as the driving force in photodynamic therapy to kill cancerous cells.  The goal of this project was to utilize mass spectrometry and parallel gas- and solution-phase reaction techniques, in conjunction with computational modeling, to explore singlet oxygen oxidation mechanisms of the five amino acid residues (methionine, cysteine, tryptophan, tyrosine, and histidine) that are most susceptible to reactive oxygen species in proteins and their dipeptides (N-acetylmethionine and cystine).  The following highlights results from specific studies.  

We first measured the oxidation reactions of individual amino acids in the gas phase using a home-made electrospray ionization guided-ion-beam scattering tandem mass spectrometer.  Quantitative measurements were carried out on the effects of collision energy, amino acid ionization and charge states, and peptide bond on reaction products, reaction thermodynamics and cross sections (micro-analogue of reaction rates).  Gas-phase experiments distinguished the intrinsic reactivities of amino acids from the solvent and counter-ions effects, and provided a basis for understanding their oxidation mechanisms.  One unexpected and biologically significant finding is that during the oxidation of these amino acids, short-lived singlet oxygen converted to stable and long-lived hydrogen peroxide that could diffuse to distant targets in biological systems and thus became more bio-toxic.  

We then investigated the same gas-phase reaction systems with an explicit number of water molecules attached to amino acid ions.  The presence of hydrogen-bonded water could intrinsically influence oxidation pathways of amino acids, and the pathways that were normally not feasible in the gas phase became effective within hydrated clusters.  Measurement of single biomolecules in gaseous hydrated clusters probed the effects of individual water molecules on amino acid oxidation, explored the question of how many water molecules are sufficient to approach solution-phase chemistry, and thus bridged gas- and solution-phase studies.  Particularly, hydrated clusters provided a valuable approach to capture short-lived peroxide intermediates of amino acids, which otherwise either decomposed in the gas phase or underwent secondary reactions in solution and thus were never directly detected in previous experiments.  

Finally, we studied the oxidation of amino acids in aqueous solution at different pH, using a newly developed on-line kinetic monitoring system which coupled real-time spectroscopy measurements with tandem mass spectrometry.  Our gas-phase experiments focused on revealing the early-stage oxidation dynamics; our solution-phase measurements, on the other hand, determined the late-stage reaction kinetics and end products.  Combination of gas- and solution-phase results, augmented by reaction potential energy surface exploration, statistical kinetic modeling and direct dynamics simulations, produced unprecedented detailed information for the oxidation mechanisms of amino acids and dipeptides.  The data we acquired for the reaction of histidine with singlet oxygen suffices a representative case, where a panorama was generated for oxidation pathways and their evolution in different media and at different ionization states.  This consists of non-oxidizability of histidine in the gas phase, formation of peroxide intermediates in hydrated clusters, and dramatic pH dependence of end-product formation in aqueous solution.  

All of our results were published in peer reviewed scientific journals and presented at major conferences.  Besides the fundamental importance of understanding biomolecule oxidation mechanisms and their biological and atmospheric implications, the present research has developed new mass spectrometric and spectroscopic techniques for examining singlet oxygen chemistry in the gas phase and in solution.

Queens College of the City University of New York is a Minority Serving Institution.  Our students represent a wide range of background, with half come from under-represented groups in science.  This project generated significant educational benefits.  Broader impacts included training one postdoctoral research associate, four doctoral graduate students (their dissertation research were supported from this grant), five Master’s students, fifteen undergraduate research students, and four high school summer research students in the areas of experimental and theoretical chemistry and instrumentation development.  The project was integrated to the Instrumental Analysis course teaching, with large efforts devoted to curriculum innovation and laboratory modernization.
